newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada's Chretien accused of avoiding Quebec issue.
newsitem.headline: Canada's Chretien accused of avoiding Quebec issue.

text.p: Quebec's place in Canada dominated the campaign for the June 2 federal election, but Prime Minister Jean Chretien was criticized for ignoring the issue on Wednesday as he announced his new cabinet.

"We note with dismay that the prime minister completely neglected to mention the unification of the country as a priority in a new government," the new opposition leader, Reform Party leader Preston Manning, told a news conference.

Quebeckers voted narrowly to stay in Canada in a 1995 referendum. Much of the recent Canadian election campaign focused on how the five major political parties would deal with Quebec's separatist sentiment.

But Chretien made few changes in his cabinet to reflect a creative approach to Quebec. All the cabinet ministers from Quebec were the same as in his first term, with only one Quebec minister changing portfolios.

The new justice minister, Anne McLellan, is from Alberta and does not speak French. The justice department will likely play a key role in any debate on the status of Quebec because the department is asking the Supreme Court of Canada to outline if Quebec can legally separate from Canada.

"It's a very good group of ministers," Chretien said, answering why he had not made significant changes in the Quebec ministers. Chretien's Liberal government was re-elected last week with a reduced majority.
"It's the status quo," complained Jacques Brassard, intergovernmental affairs minister in Quebec's separatist provincial government.
The separatist Bloc Quebecois accused Chretien of taking a "hard line" against Quebec by reappointing Stephane Dion as intergovernmental affairs minister.

Dion has been Ottawa's front man in Quebec since the 1995 referendum. He has championed the federal government's so-called Plan B, which seeks to outline how to deal with Quebec if Quebeckers vote to separate in another referendum.
Separatists, as well as Conservative leader Jean Charest, said the plan showed no willingness on the part of Ottawa to accommodate Quebec.
